title: Dad criticised for destroying eight-year-old son's artwork to teach him a lesson
text:

There's no handbook for parenting to tell us exactly how to handle each and every bizarre situation thrown our way.

Children will always make mistakes and it's our job to try and help them learn from the consequences.

But sometimes it's us who gets it wrong.

One dad-of-five took to the internet to ask for advice on whether he had correctly handled a dispute between his eight-year-old son and six-year-old daughter.

(Image: Getty)

He describes how his only boy has always been mean to his youngest sister, ever since he was two years old and she was a newborn.

In the latest episode between the pair, his daughter gave the boy a piece of paper with a drawing on it, which he promptly ripped up and told her 'this means nothing to me'.

After seeing it all unfold, the dad grabbed a craft his son had made, which he says 'was nothing sentimental and he didn't work hard on it', and destroyed it, telling his child it meant nothing to him.

"He cried and ran to my wife," said the dad on Reddit .

"She told me I shouldn't have done that and it’s different for a brother to be a jerk to their sister but I shouldn’t have stooped to his level - but I feel like it was a needed lesson and he wouldn’t do it again because now he knows how it feels."

(Image: Getty Images/iStockphoto)

After asking if he was right to give the youngster 'a taste of his own medicine', people were quick to point out where they thought he had gone wrong in the replies.

The most popular read: You're the a**hole because it’s sooo different coming from a parent vs sibling.

"There are different ways to help him see how his action made her feel.

"You say the craft you broke was something that wasn’t sentimental and he didn’t work hard on but that’s through your eyes. He’s an eight year old and it’s probably a much bigger deal to him."

Another asked: "He was acting like a child because he IS a child. Why were you acting like a child?"

The dad was quick to accept the judgement and said he would have a long hard, think about where to go from here.

He later provided an update, saying that he took his son out for breakfast where they discussed what had happened and he had apologised.

"He tried to con me into letting him have chocolate chip pancakes so I think we’re good," he added.
description: He broke his son's work and told him it 'meant nothing' to give him a taste of his own medicine
